title: 113_s2701
content: The Act titled "Stopping Illegal Obamacare Subsidies Act" limits auto-enrollment in health plans under American Health Benefit Exchanges until inconsistencies are resolved as outlined in a June 2014 report by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make public the steps to clear inconsistencies in eligibility for healthcare programs within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, methods to monitor progress in resolving inconsistencies will be disclosed within the same timeframe. The Secretary will disclose methods to monitor progress in resolving inconsistencies within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Premium assistance tax credits and cost-sharing programs will be suspended for the 2015 plan year until all inconsistencies related to invalid social security numbers are resolved. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act suspends premium tax credits and cost-sharing programs for the 2015 plan year until all inconsistencies related to invalid social security numbers are resolved. The Secretary can request additional information from individuals with inconsistent applicant information for enrollment in a qualified health plan. If applicant information for enrolling in a qualified health plan on a State or Federal Exchange is inconsistent, the Secretary can request additional information within 90 days. During this period, the individual can be enrolled in a health plan but cannot access premium assistance credits or reduced cost-sharing programs. If the individual cooperates and is later deemed eligible, they can access these programs. An individual with inconsistent applicant information for enrolling in a health plan may be requested to provide additional information within 90 days. If the individual cooperates and is later found eligible, they can retroactively receive benefits from premium assistance credits and reduced cost-sharing programs. Failure to submit additional information may result in withdrawal from these programs. If an applicant does not provide requested information, they will be withdrawn from premium assistance credit and reduced cost-sharing programs. The Secretary will notify the health insurance issuer, and the applicant must re-enroll with accurate information during the next open enrollment period. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "inconsistencies" refer to differences in self-attested information provided by an applicant for health plan enrollment and data received from the Federal Data Services Hub or other sources, including citizenship, income, employer-sponsored coverage, incarceration status, or other factors affecting eligibility for financial assistance programs. The term "inconsistencies" in the Act refers to differences in information provided by an applicant for health plan enrollment and data from sources like citizenship, income, employer-sponsored coverage, incarceration status, or other factors affecting eligibility for financial assistance programs. The "inconsistency period" is the 90-day period after notice of an inconsistency is sent to the applicant.
